MindFlayer: Efficient Asynchronous Parallel SGD
in the Presence of Heterogeneous and
Random Worker Compute Times

Artavazd Maranjyan
KAUST
arto.maranjyan@gmail.com
&Omar Shaikh Omar
KAUST
omar.shaikhomar@kaust.edu.sa
Peter RichtÃ¡rik
KAUST
peter.richtarik@kaust.edu.sa
Abstract

We study the problem of minimizing the expectation of smooth nonconvex functions with the help of several parallel workers whose role is to compute stochastic gradients. In particular, we focus on the challenging situation where the workersâ€™ compute times are arbitrarily heterogeneous and random. In the simpler regime characterized by arbitrarily heterogeneous but deterministic compute times, Tyurin and RichtÃ¡rik, (2024) recently proposed the first optimal asynchronous SGD method, called Rennala SGD, in terms of a novel complexity notion called time complexity. The starting point of our work is the observation that Rennala SGD can have arbitrarily bad performance in the presence of random compute times â€“ a setting it was not designed to handle. To advance our understanding of stochastic optimization in this challenging regime, we propose a new asynchronous SGD method, for which we coin the name MindFlayer SGD. Our theory and empirical results demonstrate the superiority of MindFlayer SGD over existing baselines, including Rennala SGD, in cases when the noise is heavy tailed.

1 Introduction

We address the nonconvex optimization problem:

minxâˆˆâ„dâ¡{fâ¢(x):=ğ”¼Î¾âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâ¢[fâ¢(x;Î¾)]},subscriptğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘assignğ‘“ğ‘¥subscriptğ”¼similar-toğœ‰ğ’Ÿdelimited-[]ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğœ‰\displaystyle\min_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\Big{\{}f(x):={\mathbb{E}}_{\xi\sim% \mathcal{D}}\left[f(x;\xi)\right]\Big{\}},roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_f ( italic_x ) := blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¾ âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f ( italic_x ; italic_Î¾ ) ] } , (1)

where f:â„dÃ—ğ•Šâ†’â„,:ğ‘“â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ•Šâ„f\,:\,\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{S}\rightarrow\mathbb{R},italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— blackboard_S â†’ blackboard_R , and Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ is a random variable with some distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D on ğ•Šğ•Š\mathbb{S}blackboard_S. In the context of machine learning, ğ•Šğ•Š\mathbb{S}blackboard_S could represent the space of all possible data, ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D denotes the distribution of the training dataset, and fâ¢(â‹…;Î¾)ğ‘“â‹…ğœ‰f(\cdot;\xi)italic_f ( â‹… ; italic_Î¾ ) denotes the loss of a data sample Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾.

The function fğ‘“fitalic_f is assumed to be differentiable, and its gradient is Lğ¿Litalic_Lâ€“Lipschitz continuous (see AssumptionsÂ 4.1â€“4.2). We assume that we have nğ‘›nitalic_n workers available to work in parallel, each able to compute independent, unbiased stochastic gradients of fğ‘“fitalic_f, whose variance is bounded by Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (see Assumption 4.3). In this paper, we are interested in investigating the time complexity of methods working in this natural setup.

1.1 Minibatch SGD

With access to nğ‘›nitalic_n clients capable of computing stochastic gradients in parallel, perhaps the most naive and classical approach is running Minibatch SGD (Cotter etÂ al., , 2011; Goyal etÂ al., , 2017; Gower etÂ al., , 2019). This method awaits the completion of all workersâ€™ computations of a single stochastic gradient before executing a gradient-type step:

  1. 1.

    receive a single stochastic gradient âˆ‡fâ¢(xk;Î¾ik)âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜ğ‘–\nabla f(x^{k};\xi^{k}_{i})âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) from each worker iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ],

  2. 2.

    update the model via xk+1=xkâˆ’Î³â¢1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nâˆ‡fâ¢(xk;Î¾ik)superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ›¾1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜ğ‘–x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\gamma\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\nabla f(x^{k};\xi^{k}_{i})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î³ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ),

where [n]:={1,â€¦,n}assigndelimited-[]ğ‘›1â€¦ğ‘›[n]:=\{1,\ldots,n\}[ italic_n ] := { 1 , â€¦ , italic_n }, Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0italic_Î³ > 0 is a stepsize, Î¾iksubscriptsuperscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜ğ‘–\xi^{k}_{i}italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are i.i.d.Â samples from ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D},caligraphic_D , and the gradients âˆ‡fâ¢(xk;Î¾ik)âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜ğ‘–\nabla f(x^{k};\xi^{k}_{i})âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) are calculated in parallel.

In real systems, each workerâ€™s computational power may differ from the others, leading to varying completion times of gradient computation. A notable drawback of Minibatch SGD is its failure to account for these differences in compute times across workers. The duration of each step is determined by the slowest workerâ€™s computation time. As a result, all other workers remain idle after completing their tasks, waiting for the slowest device to finish. Meanwhile, this idle time could potentially be used in a more efficient way to improve the overall time complexity. Clearly, a redesign of the algorithm is necessary.

1.2 Asynchronous SGD

As a result, a new generation of algorithms emerged, known as asynchronous stochastic gradient descent (ASGD) methods, designed to fully utilize all available computational resources (Recht etÂ al., , 2011; Feyzmahdavian etÂ al., , 2016; Nguyen etÂ al., , 2018; Arjevani etÂ al., , 2020; Cohen etÂ al., , 2021; Mishchenko etÂ al., , 2022; Koloskova etÂ al., , 2022; Islamov etÂ al., , 2023).

Here, the server performs a gradient-type update immediately after receiving a stochastic gradient from any worker, without waiting for the others. The updated model is then sent back to the worker, which immediately begins computing a new stochastic gradient based on the updated model. By the time the worker finishes computing this gradient, the model may have already been updated multiple times on the server due to gradients received from other workers. This creates a delay in the model update, denoted as Î´ksubscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜\delta_{k}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The algorithm can be described as follows:

  1. 1.

    receive a stochastic gradient âˆ‡fâ¢(xkâˆ’Î´k;Î¾kâˆ’Î´k)âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜superscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜\nabla f(x^{k-\delta_{k}};\xi^{k-\delta_{k}})âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) from any worker,

  2. 2.

    update the model via xk+1=xkâˆ’Î³â¢âˆ‡fâ¢(xkâˆ’Î´k;Î¾kâˆ’Î´k)superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ›¾âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜superscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\gamma\nabla f(x^{k-\delta_{k}};\xi^{k-\delta_{k}})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î³ âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ),

  3. 3.

    send new xk+1superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1x^{k+1}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to the worker so the worker computes âˆ‡fâ¢(xk+1;Î¾k+1)âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1superscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜1\nabla f(x^{k+1};\xi^{k+1})âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Cohen etÂ al., (2021); Mishchenko etÂ al., (2022); Koloskova etÂ al., (2022) showed that ASGD is provably faster in terms of time complexity then Minibatch SGD.

However, it turns out that this untamed and wild asynchrony can be detrimental. The drawback of ASGD lies in the assumption that all workersâ€™ computations are beneficial. It suffers from the issue of updating the model with potentially significantly delayed gradients, which ultimately harms convergence and, consequently, the overall time complexity, as discussed in the work of Tyurin and RichtÃ¡rik, (2024). To address this issue, there was a need to introduce a method that ignores outdated gradients while maintaining the philosophy of maximizing the utilization of available computational resources.

1.3 Rennala SGD

Such a method was proposed in a recent breakthrough by Tyurin and RichtÃ¡rik, (2024). Their method which can be viewed as a modification of the Minibatch SGD method. At each iteration the server collects a batch of gradients, but it allows workers to send as many gradients as they can on the same point xksuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x^{k}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, using this batch, Rennala SGD proceeds with a gradient-type update using this batch as in Minibatch SGD:

  1. 1.

    wait until the server receives BğµBitalic_B stochastic gradients at point xksuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x^{k}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

  2. 2.

    update the model via xk+1=xkâˆ’Î³â¢1Bâ¢âˆ‘j=1Bâˆ‡fâ¢(xk;Î¾jk)superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ›¾1ğµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğµâˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜ğ‘—x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\gamma\frac{1}{B}\sum_{j=1}^{B}\nabla f(x^{k};\xi^{k}_{j})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î³ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ),

more details on Rennala SGD are in AppendixÂ D. In this case, the faster the worker, the more gradients it sends. For the struggling workers, it may happen that they are completely ignored.

Their approach considers a setting where each worker iğ‘–iitalic_i requires a fixed Ï„i>0subscriptğœğ‘–0\tau_{i}>0italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 seconds to compute a stochastic gradient. For the first time lower bounds on time complexity were obtained for first order ASGD methods in the above mentioned fixed compute time regime for nonconvex functions with Lipschitz gradients. They showed that Rennala SGD is mini-max optimal in this setup in terms of time complexity.

While it may seem that the story is over, we want to question the fixed time assumption, arguing that a random time model is more realistic. The claim of optimality does not hold because of this randomness, suggesting that the algorithms need to be reevaluated and redesigned. We believe that a redesign is necessary to better fit this more realistic approach.

2 Problem Setup and Contributions

The deterministic compute time setup considered by Tyurin and RichtÃ¡rik, (2024), where Rennala SGD is optimal, fails to capture the complexities of real-world distributed learning environments. In practice, compute times are often uncertain due to various factors such as failing hardware, preemption by other jobs, delays in GPU computation, and inconsistencies in network communications (Chen etÂ al., , 2016; Dutta etÂ al., , 2018). This uncertainty is even more pronounced in federated learning scenarios, where client unreliability can lead to unpredictable computation times or even incomplete tasks (Kairouz etÂ al., , 2021).

2.1 Random compute times

To address these real-world challenges, we propose a more practical setup that incorporates randomness into compute times. Specifically, we consider a scenario where the stochastic gradient computation time of worker iğ‘–iitalic_i is given by:

Ï„i+Î·i,subscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\tau_{i}+\eta_{i},italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (2)

where Ï„i>0subscriptğœğ‘–0\tau_{i}>0italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 is a constant representing the minimum time for client iğ‘–iitalic_i to complete the gradient computation, and Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a non-negative random variable drawn from some distribution ğ’¥isubscriptğ’¥ğ‘–\mathcal{J}_{i}caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, modeling the aforementioned uncertainties.

In this more realistic setting, existing methods like Rennala SGD and ASGD can perform poorly or even fail to converge. We can illustrate this with a simple example:

Consider a scenario where each time we request a device to compute a stochastic gradient, one of two outcomes occurs. Either the device completes the computation exactly after the minimum time Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ without any delays, or something goes wrong and the computation is never completed. This situation can be modeled using a random time Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· as follows:

Î·={0,with probabilityÂ â¢1âˆ’q,âˆ,with probabilityÂ â¢q,ğœ‚cases0with probabilityÂ 1ğ‘with probabilityÂ ğ‘\eta=\begin{cases}0,&\text{with probability }1-q,\\ \infty,&\text{with probability }q,\end{cases}italic_Î· = { start_ROW start_CELL 0 , end_CELL start_CELL with probability 1 - italic_q , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL âˆ , end_CELL start_CELL with probability italic_q , end_CELL end_ROW (3)

where 0<q<10ğ‘10<q<10 < italic_q < 1. In this scenario, any method that waits for a certain number of batches on each iteration to perform a step runs the risk of never receiving the required batch and getting stuck. This includes methods like Rennala SGD or ASGD. Specifically, if the algorithm waits for a single stochastic gradient on each iteration, there is a probability qnsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘›q^{n}italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that it will never receive it and consequently never proceed.

2.2 Summary of contributions

To address these limitations, we propose a new method that, unlike Rennala SGD or ASGD, does not wait for a fixed number of gradients (such as one in ASGD). Instead, it allocates a specific time for computing each stochastic gradient. If a client fails to complete its computation within the designated time, the partial computation is discarded, and a new computation is initiated. Our main contributions are as follows.

  • â€¢

    In SectionÂ 4, we propose a new time efficient asynchronous parallel stochastic gradient descent method, MindFlayer SGD (FootnoteÂ 7), for the heterogeneous and random worker compute times regime (EquationÂ 2). To the best of our knowledge, MindFlayer SGD is the first algorithm designed to work in this regime. We show that our method is a generalization of Rennala SGD, meaning that it is optimal in the deterministic compute times setup.

  • â€¢

    In SectionÂ 5, we show that the theoretical time complexity of MindFlayer SGD can be arbitrarily faster than that of Rennala SGD or ASGD, depending on the distributions of computation times. Specifically, we demonstrate that if the distributions of computation times ğ’¥isubscriptğ’¥ğ‘–\mathcal{J}_{i}caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are positively skewed, our method is faster, with the performance gap increasing as the skewness coefficient grows. As shown in FootnoteÂ 3, where ğ’¥i=Lognormalâ¢(0,s)subscriptğ’¥ğ‘–Lognormal0ğ‘ \mathcal{J}_{i}=\text{Lognormal}(0,s)caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = Lognormal ( 0 , italic_s ). As sğ‘ sitalic_s gets bigger, the distributionâ€™s skewness coefficient gets bigger and the performance of Rennala SGD or ASGD gets worse. Meanwhile, our method MindFlayer SGD is robust to the change of the variance.

  • â€¢

    In SectionÂ 6, we experimentally validate this performance. We provide practical guidelines for using MindFlayer SGD, and demonstrate its superiority over Rennala SGD and ASGD. We conduct evaluations using various functions and distributions. For distributions, we consider Lognormal, Log-Cauchy, and the Infinite-Bernoulli (defined by EquationÂ 3) distributions. Regarding the functions, we consider a quadratic loss and a neural network on the MNIST (LeCun etÂ al., , 1998) dataset. This diverse testing setup enables us to showcase MindFlayer SGDâ€™s robustness and effectiveness across various challenging scenarios.

  • â€¢

    In AppendixÂ C, we expand our theory to develop Vecna SGD, designed for the heterogeneous case, where workers have datasets that are coming from different distributions.

3 Motivation and Single Device Case

To illustrate the motivation behind the design of our new method, let us consider a single device setup. Recall the scenario introduced in EquationÂ 3 where we have single device and it either returns a gradient after Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ time or gets stuck with probability qğ‘qitalic_q. A straightforward and optimal workaround to this issue is to wait exactly Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ seconds. If we do not receive a gradient within this time frame, it indicates that we will never receive it, so there is no point in waiting longer. In this case, we discard the current computation, which would take forever anyway, and request the device to compute the gradient again. The probability of getting stuck again is lower, so eventually, we will receive a gradient and move forward.

More generally, consider the following two strategies for each step:

  • â€¢

    Strategy 1: Rennala SGD. We wait for the first BğµBitalic_B stochastic gradients. Thus, the time for one step for this strategy is the random variable:

    TB=âˆ‘j=1B(Ï„+Î·j).subscriptğ‘‡ğµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğµğœsuperscriptğœ‚ğ‘—T_{B}=\sum_{j=1}^{B}(\tau+\eta^{j}).italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ + italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .
  • â€¢

    Strategy 2: MindFlayer SGD. We repeat the following random trial BğµBitalic_B times: allocate time tğ‘¡titalic_t for computing a stochastic gradient. If we do not receive a stochastic gradient within that time, discard the current computation and start over. Then the time for the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th trial is given by:

    Tjâ¢(t)={Ï„+Î·j,ifâ¢Î·jâ‰¤t,Ï„+t,ifâ¢Î·j>t.superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘—ğ‘¡casesğœsuperscriptğœ‚ğ‘—ifsuperscriptğœ‚ğ‘—ğ‘¡ğœğ‘¡ifsuperscriptğœ‚ğ‘—ğ‘¡T^{j}(t)=\begin{cases}\tau+\eta^{j},&\text{if}\enspace\eta^{j}\leq t,\\ \tau+t,&\text{if}\enspace\eta^{j}>t.\end{cases}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_Ï„ + italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL if italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_t , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_Ï„ + italic_t , end_CELL start_CELL if italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > italic_t . end_CELL end_ROW

    Thus, the time for one step for this strategy is the random variable:

    T~Bâ¢(t)=âˆ‘j=1BTjâ¢(t).subscript~ğ‘‡ğµğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğµsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘—ğ‘¡\tilde{T}_{B}(t)=\sum_{j=1}^{B}T^{j}(t).over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) .

In the second case, rather than waiting for BğµBitalic_B gradients, we attempt to compute BğµBitalic_B gradients. Essentially, we limit the time spent on computing a stochastic gradient. In expectation, Strategy 2 will collect Bâ¢pğµğ‘Bpitalic_B italic_p gradients per iteration, where p=Pâ¢(Î·â‰¤t)ğ‘ğ‘ƒğœ‚ğ‘¡p=P(\eta\leq t)italic_p = italic_P ( italic_Î· â‰¤ italic_t ) is the probability of collecting a gradient within a trial. Setting t=âˆğ‘¡t=\inftyitalic_t = âˆ removes this restriction, resulting in the same strategy as the first one, Rennala SGD.

For MindFlayer SGD, each iteration, on average, receives only Bâ¢pğµğ‘Bpitalic_B italic_p gradients, making it effectively a scaled-down version of Rennala SGD. Consequently, MindFlayer SGD is expected to require 1/p1ğ‘1/p1 / italic_p times more iterations than Rennala SGD to achieve the same level of convergence. We have the following proposition.

Proposition 3.1 (Proof in AppendixÂ F).

Let Kğ¾Kitalic_K be the number of iterations required by Rennala SGD to find an Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ-stationary point. Then, for sufficiently small Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ, MindFlayer SGD needs K/pğ¾ğ‘K/pitalic_K / italic_p iterations to find an Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ-stationary point.

Thus, the time complexities in this setting are given by:

Tğ–±ğ–¾ğ—‡ğ—‡ğ–ºğ—…ğ–ºğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£=Kâ¢ğ”¼â¢[TB]=Kâ¢Bâ¢(Ï„+ğ”¼â¢[Î·]),subscriptğ‘‡ğ–±ğ–¾ğ—‡ğ—‡ğ–ºğ—…ğ–ºğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‡ğµğ¾ğµğœğ”¼delimited-[]ğœ‚\displaystyle T_{{\sf\footnotesize\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}\definecolor[% named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}RennalaSGD}}=K\mathbb{E}\left[T_{B}% \right]=KB(\tau+\mathbb{E}\left[\eta\right]),italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_RennalaSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_K blackboard_E [ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = italic_K italic_B ( italic_Ï„ + blackboard_E [ italic_Î· ] ) ,
Tğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¥ğ—…ğ–ºğ—’ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£â¢(t)=Kpâ¢ğ”¼â¢[T~Bâ¢(t)]=Kpâ¢Bâ¢(Ï„+(1âˆ’p)â¢t+pâ¢ğ”¼â¢[Ï„|Ï„â‰¤t])â‰¤Kpâ¢Bâ¢(Ï„+t).subscriptğ‘‡ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¥ğ—…ğ–ºğ—’ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£ğ‘¡ğ¾ğ‘ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~ğ‘‡ğµğ‘¡ğ¾ğ‘ğµğœ1ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalğœğœğ‘¡ğ¾ğ‘ğµğœğ‘¡\displaystyle T_{{\sf\footnotesize\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}\definecolor[% named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}MindFlayerSGD}}(t)=\frac{K}{p}% \mathbb{E}\left[\tilde{T}_{B}(t)\right]=\frac{K}{p}B(\tau+(1-p)t+p\mathbb{E}% \left[\tau|\tau\leq t\right])\leq\frac{K}{p}B(\tau+t).italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_MindFlayerSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_p end_ARG blackboard_E [ over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ] = divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_p end_ARG italic_B ( italic_Ï„ + ( 1 - italic_p ) italic_t + italic_p blackboard_E [ italic_Ï„ | italic_Ï„ â‰¤ italic_t ] ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_p end_ARG italic_B ( italic_Ï„ + italic_t ) .

This leads us to the following observation.

Remark 3.2.

For the case where n=1ğ‘›1n=1italic_n = 1, MindFlayer SGD is faster than Rennala SGD if there exists a time threshold t>0ğ‘¡0t>0italic_t > 0 such that the following inequality holds:

Ï„+tPâ¢(Î·â‰¤t)<Ï„+ğ”¼â¢[Î·].ğœğ‘¡ğ‘ƒğœ‚ğ‘¡ğœğ”¼delimited-[]ğœ‚\frac{\tau+t}{P(\eta\leq t)}<\tau+\mathbb{E}\left[\eta\right].divide start_ARG italic_Ï„ + italic_t end_ARG start_ARG italic_P ( italic_Î· â‰¤ italic_t ) end_ARG < italic_Ï„ + blackboard_E [ italic_Î· ] .

It is important to note that this can hold for a wide range of values of tğ‘¡titalic_t, including any finite value. The latter is particularly relevant in cases where ğ”¼â¢[Î·]=âˆğ”¼delimited-[]ğœ‚\mathbb{E}\left[\eta\right]=\inftyblackboard_E [ italic_Î· ] = âˆ. An example of such a scenario is illustrated in EquationÂ 3. There are many other distributions for which the expectation is not finite, such as the Log-Cauchy distribution, LÃ©vy distribution, Log-t distribution, Landau distribution, and so forth.

A less restrictive example of distributions are positively skewed distributions. Let s=ğ”¼â¢[Î·]âˆ’Medâ¢[Î·]ğ‘ ğ”¼delimited-[]ğœ‚Meddelimited-[]ğœ‚s=\mathbb{E}\left[\eta\right]-\mathrm{Med}[\eta]italic_s = blackboard_E [ italic_Î· ] - roman_Med [ italic_Î· ] be the skewness coefficient of the distribution ğ’¥ğ’¥\mathcal{J}caligraphic_J. If s>0ğ‘ 0s>0italic_s > 0 we say that the distribution is positively skewed. Then we have the following proposition.

Proposition 3.3.

[Proof in AppendixÂ F] For the n=1ğ‘›1n=1italic_n = 1 case, if s>Ï„+Medâ¢[Î·]ğ‘ ğœMeddelimited-[]ğœ‚s>\tau+\mathrm{Med}[\eta]italic_s > italic_Ï„ + roman_Med [ italic_Î· ] then MindFlayer SGD is faster than Rennala SGD. Moreover, if s=(Ï„+Medâ¢[Î·])â¢(2â¢Î±âˆ’1)ğ‘ ğœMeddelimited-[]ğœ‚2ğ›¼1s=\left(\tau+\mathrm{Med}[\eta]\right)\left(2\alpha-1\right)italic_s = ( italic_Ï„ + roman_Med [ italic_Î· ] ) ( 2 italic_Î± - 1 ) then

Tğ–±ğ–¾ğ—‡ğ—‡ğ–ºğ—…ğ–ºğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£Tğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¥ğ—…ğ–ºğ—’ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£â¢(Medâ¢[Î·])â‰¥Î±.subscriptğ‘‡ğ–±ğ–¾ğ—‡ğ—‡ğ–ºğ—…ğ–ºğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£subscriptğ‘‡ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¥ğ—…ğ–ºğ—’ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£Meddelimited-[]ğœ‚ğ›¼\frac{T_{{\sf\footnotesize\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}\definecolor[named]{% pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}RennalaSGD}}}{T_{{\sf\footnotesize\color[% rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}% MindFlayerSGD}}\left(\mathrm{Med}[\eta]\right)}\geq\alpha.divide start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_RennalaSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_MindFlayerSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Med [ italic_Î· ] ) end_ARG â‰¥ italic_Î± .

Therefore, Rennala SGD can be arbitrarily bad. As an example consider the Lognormal(Î¼,Ïƒ2)ğœ‡superscriptğœ2(\mu,\sigma^{2})( italic_Î¼ , italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) distribution. For this distribution, we have:

s=ğ”¼â¢[Î·]âˆ’Medâ¢[Î·]=expâ¡(Î¼+Ïƒ22)âˆ’expâ¡(Î¼).ğ‘ ğ”¼delimited-[]ğœ‚Meddelimited-[]ğœ‚ğœ‡superscriptğœ22ğœ‡s=\mathbb{E}\left[\eta\right]-\mathrm{Med}[\eta]=\exp\left(\mu+\frac{\sigma^{2% }}{2}\right)-\exp(\mu).italic_s = blackboard_E [ italic_Î· ] - roman_Med [ italic_Î· ] = roman_exp ( italic_Î¼ + divide start_ARG italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) - roman_exp ( italic_Î¼ ) .

Thus, as we increase Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ, the difference becomes arbitrarily large.

To verify this, we also conducted a small experiment, see FootnoteÂ 5. The right plot showcases how the ratio of time complexity between Rennala SGD and MindFlayer SGD can get arbitrarily large for the optimal clipping time tâˆ—:=argâ¡mintâ¡Tğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¥ğ—…ğ–ºğ—’ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£â¢(t)assignsuperscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¥ğ—…ğ–ºğ—’ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£ğ‘¡t^{*}:=\arg\min_{t}T_{{{\sf\footnotesize\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}% \definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}MindFlayerSGD}}}(t)italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_MindFlayerSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) and even the median of the distribution tmedian=Medâ¢[Î·]subscriptğ‘¡medianMeddelimited-[]ğœ‚t_{\text{median}}=\mathrm{Med}[\eta]italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT median end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Med [ italic_Î· ]. The left and middle plots showcase the potential improvement, and even loss from choosing different clipping times tğ‘¡titalic_t.

4 MindFlayer SGD

Here, we propose our MindFlayer SGD algorithm for multiple device case (n>1ğ‘›1n>1italic_n > 1). For the heterogeneous case, please refer to AppendixÂ C.

The MindFlayer SGD algorithm begins with an initialization at a starting point x0superscriptğ‘¥0x^{0}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with a specified stepsize Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0italic_Î³ > 0, time allowances ti>0subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–0t_{i}>0italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0, and trial counts Biâ‰¥0subscriptğµğ‘–0B_{i}\geq 0italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0 for each client. In each iteration kğ‘˜kitalic_k, ranging from k=1ğ‘˜1k=1italic_k = 1 to Kğ¾Kitalic_K, the server distributes the current point xksuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x^{k}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to all clients. Each client iğ‘–iitalic_i then executes a subroutine (AlgorithmÂ 2) to attempt to compute Bisubscriptğµğ‘–B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT stochastic gradients from samples Î¾ijsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–ğ‘—\xi_{i}^{j}italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT drawn from a distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. During each attempt, client iğ‘–iitalic_i starts computing a stochastic gradient; if the computation exceeds the allotted time tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, they discard the current gradient and begin another computation. Consequently, the actual number of stochastic gradients received from each client iğ‘–iitalic_i becomes a random variable, ranging from 00 to Bisubscriptğµğ‘–B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The expected number of gradients from client iğ‘–iitalic_i is given by piâ¢Bisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğµğ‘–p_{i}B_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, leading to an overall expected total of stochastic gradients B=âˆ‘i=1npiâ¢Biğµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğµğ‘–B=\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}B_{i}italic_B = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The server aggregates these received stochastic gradients and normalizes the collective gradient by the expected batch size BğµBitalic_B. Finally, the point is updated to xk+1=xkâˆ’Î³â¢gksuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ›¾superscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\gamma g^{k}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î³ italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT following each aggregation round.

In the special case where the computation time is deterministic, i.e., Î·i=0subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–0\eta_{i}=0italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 for every worker iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ], we have pi=1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1p_{i}=1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 for all iğ‘–iitalic_i. While Rennala SGD does not explicitly specify the number of gradient computations Bisubscriptğµğ‘–B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each client, in the deterministic setting, each client will send a fixed number of gradients per communication round. Consequently, for any t>0ğ‘¡0t>0italic_t > 0, MindFlayer SGD FootnoteÂ 7, by choosing Bisubscriptğµğ‘–B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT appropriately, reduces to Rennala SGD AlgorithmÂ 5.

However, the situation changes when Î·i>0subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–0\eta_{i}>0italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 is not a constant random variable. If we set ti=âˆsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}=\inftyitalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ for all iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ], MindFlayer SGD FootnoteÂ 7 does not reduce to Rennala SGD AlgorithmÂ 5. This is because, in the case of Rennala SGD, the randomness in each iteration causes the number of stochastic gradients computed by each client to vary across different communication rounds. Nevertheless, this scenario is not our primary focus, as we will demonstrate that allowing each worker to complete its gradient computation by setting ti=âˆsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}=\inftyitalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ is inefficient when dealing with positively skewed distributions.

To continue with the analysis of MindFlayer SGD, we first present the assumptions under which this method is studied.

4.1 Assumptions

We consider standard assumptions used in the nonconvex optimization.

Assumption 4.1.

Function fğ‘“fitalic_f is differentiable, and its gradient is Lğ¿Litalic_Lâ€“Lipschitz continuous, i.e., â€–âˆ‡fâ¢(x)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ¢(y)â€–â‰¤Lâ¢â€–xâˆ’yâ€–normâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¥âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¦ğ¿normğ‘¥ğ‘¦\left\|\nabla f(x)-\nabla f(y)\right\|\leq L\left\|x-y\right\|âˆ¥ âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x ) - âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_y ) âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_L âˆ¥ italic_x - italic_y âˆ¥, for all x,yâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_x , italic_y âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Assumption 4.2.

There exist finfâˆˆâ„superscriptğ‘“infimumâ„f^{\inf}\in\mathbb{R}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_inf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R such that fâ¢(x)â‰¥finfğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘“infimumf(x)\geq f^{\inf}italic_f ( italic_x ) â‰¥ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_inf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Assumption 4.3.

For all xâˆˆâ„d,ğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d},italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , stochastic gradients âˆ‡fâ¢(x;Î¾)âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğœ‰\nabla f(x;\xi)âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x ; italic_Î¾ ) are unbiased and Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-variance-bounded, i.e., ğ”¼Î¾â¢[âˆ‡fâ¢(x;Î¾)]=âˆ‡fâ¢(x)subscriptğ”¼ğœ‰delimited-[]âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğœ‰âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¥{\mathbb{E}}_{\xi}\left[\nabla f(x;\xi)\right]=\nabla f(x)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¾ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x ; italic_Î¾ ) ] = âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x ) and ğ”¼Î¾â¢[â€–âˆ‡fâ¢(x;Î¾)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ¢(x)â€–2]â‰¤Ïƒ2subscriptğ”¼ğœ‰delimited-[]superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğœ‰âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¥2superscriptğœ2{\mathbb{E}}_{\xi}\left[\left\|\nabla f(x;\xi)-\nabla f(x)\right\|^{2}\right]% \leq\sigma^{2}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¾ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ¥ âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x ; italic_Î¾ ) - âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where Ïƒ2â‰¥0superscriptğœ20\sigma^{2}\geq 0italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ 0.

4.2 Convergence theory

The following theorem gives iterations guarantees for the convergence of Rennala SGD.

Even though MindFlayer SGD is similar to Rennala SGD the convergence analysis require additional considerations, since the batch size is a random variable here as apposed to the case of Rennala SGD.

Theorem 4.4.

Assume that AssumptionsÂ 4.1, 4.2 and 4.3 hold. Let B=âˆ‘i=1npiâ¢Biğµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğµğ‘–B=\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}B_{i}italic_B = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Î³=12â¢Lâ¢minâ¡{1,Îµâ¢BÏƒ2}ğ›¾12ğ¿1ğœ€ğµsuperscriptğœ2\gamma=\frac{1}{2L}\min\left\{1,\frac{\varepsilon B}{\sigma^{2}}\right\}italic_Î³ = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG roman_min { 1 , divide start_ARG italic_Îµ italic_B end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG } in FootnoteÂ 7. Then, after

Kâ‰¥maxâ¡{1,Ïƒ2Îµâ¢B}â¢8â¢Lâ¢(fâ¢(x0)âˆ’finf)Îµğ¾1superscriptğœ2ğœ€ğµ8ğ¿ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘“infimumğœ€K\geq\max\left\{1,\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon B}\right\}\frac{8L\left(f(x^{0% })-f^{\inf}\right)}{\varepsilon}italic_K â‰¥ roman_max { 1 , divide start_ARG italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ italic_B end_ARG } divide start_ARG 8 italic_L ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_inf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG

iterations, the method guarantees that 1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=0Kâˆ’1ğ”¼â¢[â€–âˆ‡fâ¢(xk)â€–2]â‰¤Îµ1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ¾1ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜2ğœ€\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}{\mathbb{E}}\left[\left\|\nabla f(x^{k})\right\|^{2% }\right]\leq\varepsilondivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ âˆ¥ âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ italic_Îµ.

Sketch of Proof.

(Complete proof in SectionÂ G.1) We consider FootnoteÂ 7 as a conventional SGD using the following gradient estimator:

gâ¢(x)=1Bâ¢âˆ‘i=1nâˆ‘j=1BiIâ¢(Î·ijâ‰¤ti)â¢âˆ‡fâ¢(x;Î¾ij),ğ‘”ğ‘¥1ğµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğµğ‘–ğ¼superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–ğ‘—g(x)=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{j=1}^{B_{i}}I(\eta_{i}^{j}\leq t_{i})% \nabla f(x;\xi_{i}^{j}),italic_g ( italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I ( italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x ; italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ,

where Iâ¢(â‹…)ğ¼â‹…I(\cdot)italic_I ( â‹… ) denotes the indicator function. Prior to applying the classical SGD theorem (TheoremÂ E.2), it is essential to verify that this estimator meets the theoremâ€™s conditions, namely unbiasedness and a specific bound on the second moment of gâ¢(x)ğ‘”ğ‘¥g(x)italic_g ( italic_x ). We demonstrate that the estimator is unbiased, and that

ğ”¼â¢[â€–gâ¢(x)2â€–]â‰¤2â¢â€–âˆ‡fâ¢(x)â€–2+1Bâ¢Ïƒ2.ğ”¼delimited-[]normğ‘”superscriptğ‘¥22superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¥21ğµsuperscriptğœ2\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|g(x)^{2}\right\|\right]\leq 2\left\|\nabla f(x)\right\|% ^{2}+\frac{1}{B}\sigma^{2}.blackboard_E [ âˆ¥ italic_g ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ ] â‰¤ 2 âˆ¥ âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

With these conditions satisfied, we can proceed to apply TheoremÂ E.2. âˆ

Note that in the deterministic case where Î·i=0subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–0\eta_{i}=0italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 for all iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ], we have pi=Pâ¢(Î·iâ‰¤ti)=1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–1p_{i}=P(\eta_{i}\leq t_{i})=1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_P ( italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1 for all iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ]. Therefore, we derive

Kâ‰¥maxâ¡{1,Ïƒ2Îµâ¢B}â¢8â¢Lâ¢(fâ¢(x0)âˆ’finf)Îµ,ğ¾1superscriptğœ2ğœ€ğµ8ğ¿ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘“infimumğœ€K\geq\max\left\{1,\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon B}\right\}\frac{8L\left(f(x^{0% })-f^{\inf}\right)}{\varepsilon},italic_K â‰¥ roman_max { 1 , divide start_ARG italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ italic_B end_ARG } divide start_ARG 8 italic_L ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_inf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG ,

with B=âˆ‘i=1nBiğµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğµğ‘–B=\sum_{i=1}^{n}B_{i}italic_B = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, yielding the same result as Rennala SGD, up to a constant factor.

We also achieve the same rate as tiâ†’âˆâ†’subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}\to\inftyitalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ âˆ for all iğ‘–iitalic_i, since in that scenario piâ†’1â†’subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1p_{i}\to 1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ 1. This is expected because we will observe a consistent number of stochastic gradients each time, though the timing may vary, as mentioned earlier.

However, if ti=0subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–0t_{i}=0italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 for all iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ], then K=âˆğ¾K=\inftyitalic_K = âˆ. This result is anticipated since, in this case, the success probability is zero for all clients, and thus the server never receives stochastic gradients.

4.3 Time Complexity

The following theorem gives time complexity for MindFlayer SGD.

Theorem 4.5 (Proof in SectionÂ G.2).

Assume that AssumptionsÂ 4.1, 4.2 and 4.3 hold. Let B=âˆ‘i=1npiâ¢Biğµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğµğ‘–B=\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}B_{i}italic_B = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Î³=12â¢Lâ¢minâ¡{1,Îµâ¢BÏƒ2}ğ›¾12ğ¿1ğœ€ğµsuperscriptğœ2\gamma=\frac{1}{2L}\min\left\{1,\frac{\varepsilon B}{\sigma^{2}}\right\}italic_Î³ = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG roman_min { 1 , divide start_ARG italic_Îµ italic_B end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG } in MethodÂ 7. Let t=(t1,â€¦,tn)ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›t=\left(t_{1},\ldots,t_{n}\right)italic_t = ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), t1,â€¦,tnâ‰¥0subscriptğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›0t_{1},\ldots,t_{n}\geq 0italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0. Without loss of generality assume that 0<Ï„1+t1â‰¤â‹¯â‰¤Ï„n+tn0subscriptğœ1subscriptğ‘¡1â‹¯subscriptğœğ‘›subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›0<\tau_{1}+t_{1}\leq\cdots\leq\tau_{n}+t_{n}0 < italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ â‹¯ â‰¤ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let

tâ¢(m)=(âˆ‘j=1mpjÏ„j+tj)âˆ’1â¢(S+âˆ‘j=1mpj),ğ‘¡ğ‘šsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘—subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—1ğ‘†superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—t(m)=\left(\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{p_{j}}{\tau_{j}+t_{j}}\right)^{-1}\left(S+\sum_% {j=1}^{m}p_{j}\right),italic_t ( italic_m ) = ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_S + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

where S=maxâ¡{1,Ïƒ2Îµ}ğ‘†1superscriptğœ2ğœ€S=\max\left\{1,\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon}\right\}italic_S = roman_max { 1 , divide start_ARG italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG }. Let mâˆ—=argâ¡minmâˆˆ[n]â¡tâ¢(m)superscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ‘šdelimited-[]ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘šm^{*}=\arg\min_{m\in[n]}t(m)italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ( italic_m ), if there are several minimizers we take the smallest one. Put

Bi=âŒˆbiâŒ‰,bi={tâ¢(mâˆ—)Ï„i+tiâˆ’1,ifâ¢iâ‰¤mâˆ—,0,ifâ¢i>mâˆ—.formulae-sequencesubscriptğµğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–casesğ‘¡superscriptğ‘šsubscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–1ifğ‘–superscriptğ‘š0ifğ‘–superscriptğ‘šB_{i}=\lceil b_{i}\rceil,\quad b_{i}=\begin{cases}\frac{t(m^{*})}{\tau_{i}+t_{% i}}-1,&\text{if}\enspace i\leq m^{*},\\ 0,&\text{if}\enspace i>m^{*}.\end{cases}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âŒˆ italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŒ‰ , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG italic_t ( italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - 1 , end_CELL start_CELL if italic_i â‰¤ italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 , end_CELL start_CELL if italic_i > italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW

Then, MindFlayer SGD guarantees to find an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-stationary point after

Tğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¥ğ—…ğ–ºğ—’ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£â¢(t)â‰¥8Ã—minmâˆˆ[n]â¡{(1mâ¢âˆ‘j=1mpjÏ„j+tj)âˆ’1â¢(Sm+1mâ¢âˆ‘j=1mpj)â¢Î”â¢LÎµ}subscriptğ‘‡ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¥ğ—…ğ–ºğ—’ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£ğ‘¡8subscriptğ‘šdelimited-[]ğ‘›superscript1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘—subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—1ğ‘†ğ‘š1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—Î”ğ¿ğœ€T_{{{\sf\footnotesize\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}\definecolor[named]{% pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}MindFlayerSGD}}}(t)\geq 8\times\min_{m\in[% n]}\left\{\left(\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{p_{j}}{\tau_{j}+t_{j}}\right)^{% -1}\left(\frac{S}{m}+\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}p_{j}\right)\frac{\Delta L}{% \varepsilon}\right\}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_MindFlayerSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) â‰¥ 8 Ã— roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG roman_Î” italic_L end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG }

seconds, where Î”=fâ¢(x0)âˆ’finfÎ”ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘“infimum\Delta=f(x_{0})-f^{\inf}roman_Î” = italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_inf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

The theorem indicates that the optimal strategy is to disregard devices with a high value of Ï„i+ti/pisubscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–\nicefrac{{\tau_{i}+t_{i}}}{{p_{i}}}/ start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. Therefore, we should prioritize devices that not only have a high probability pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of completing the gradient within the allotted time tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but also have a relatively small sum of Ï„i+tisubscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–\tau_{i}+t_{i}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This approach is logical as it avoids including devices with substantial computation times and low probabilities of completing their tasks within the specified duration.

In the deterministic case where Î·i=0subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–0\eta_{i}=0italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 for all iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ], we have pi=1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1p_{i}=1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 for all iğ‘–iitalic_i. Consequently, the time complexity of MindFlayer SGD at time tğ‘¡titalic_t is given by

Tğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¥ğ—…ğ–ºğ—’ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£â¢(t)â‰¥8Ã—minmâˆˆ[n]â¡{(1mâ¢âˆ‘j=1m1Ï„j+tj)âˆ’1â¢(Sm+1)â¢Î”â¢LÎµ}.subscriptğ‘‡ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¥ğ—…ğ–ºğ—’ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£ğ‘¡8subscriptğ‘šdelimited-[]ğ‘›superscript1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘š1subscriptğœğ‘—subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—1ğ‘†ğ‘š1Î”ğ¿ğœ€T_{{{\sf\footnotesize\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}\definecolor[named]{% pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}MindFlayerSGD}}}(t)\geq 8\times\min_{m\in[% n]}\left\{\left(\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{1}{\tau_{j}+t_{j}}\right)^{-1}% \left(\frac{S}{m}+1\right)\frac{\Delta L}{\varepsilon}\right\}.italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_MindFlayerSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) â‰¥ 8 Ã— roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG + 1 ) divide start_ARG roman_Î” italic_L end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG } .

Thus, the optimal choice of tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is ti=0subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–0t_{i}=0italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 for all iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ]. Therefore, the final time complexity becomes

Tğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¥ğ—…ğ–ºğ—’ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£â¢(t)â‰¥8Ã—minmâˆˆ[n]â¡{(1mâ¢âˆ‘j=1m1Ï„j)âˆ’1â¢(1m+1)â¢Î”â¢LÎµ}.subscriptğ‘‡ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¥ğ—…ğ–ºğ—’ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¦ğ–£ğ‘¡8subscriptğ‘šdelimited-[]ğ‘›superscript1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘š1subscriptğœğ‘—11ğ‘š1Î”ğ¿ğœ€T_{{{\sf\footnotesize\color[rgb]{0.75390625,0,0}\definecolor[named]{% pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.75390625,0,0}MindFlayerSGD}}}(t)\geq 8\times\min_{m\in[% n]}\left\{\left(\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{1}{\tau_{j}}\right)^{-1}\left(% \frac{1}{m}+1\right)\frac{\Delta L}{\varepsilon}\right\}.italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_MindFlayerSGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) â‰¥ 8 Ã— roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG + 1 ) divide start_ARG roman_Î” italic_L end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG } .

This formulation recovers the time complexity for Rennala SGD.

We still have the freedom to choose the tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT allocation times. The optimal strategy would be to select them in a manner that minimizes the time complexity. As observed in FootnoteÂ 5, setting ti=Medâ¢[Î·i]subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–Meddelimited-[]subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–t_{i}=\mathrm{Med}\left[\eta_{i}\right]italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Med [ italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] proves to be a viable choice. This is further confirmed by our experiments in SectionÂ 6.

5 Comparing to Rennala SGD

Comparing the theoretical performance of Rennala SGD and MindFlayer SGD is particularly challenging due to the inherent randomness in the time complexity of Rennala SGD and the dependence of MindFlayer SGD on optimizing time variables tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For example, a comparison using the expected time complexity may fail to capture the nuances of each algorithmâ€™s performance across different distributions. Thus, we turn to an empirical comparison to provide insights into their practical behavior. In particular, we aim to demonstrate how MindFlayer SGD can achieve arbitrarily better performance in scenarios where the distributions are positively skewed (see Figure 3).

To begin, we derive the time complexity of Rennala SGD in the context of random times. Let â„¬:={(B1,B2,â€¦,Bn):Biâˆˆâ„•0;âˆ‘i=1nBi=B}assignâ„¬conditional-setsubscriptğµ1subscriptğµ2â€¦subscriptğµğ‘›formulae-sequencesubscriptğµğ‘–subscriptâ„•0superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğµğ‘–ğµ\mathcal{B}:=\left\{(B_{1},B_{2},\ldots,B_{n}):B_{i}\in\mathbb{N}_{0};\sum_{i=% 1}^{n}B_{i}=B\right\}caligraphic_B := { ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) : italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_B } be the set of all possible batch sizes for each device, the time TBsubscriptğ‘‡ğµT_{B}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT required for one step with batch size BğµBitalic_B of Rennala SGD is given by:

TBsubscriptğ‘‡ğµ\displaystyle T_{B}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =minâ„¬â¡{maxiâˆˆ[1,n]â¡{Biâ¢Ï„i+âˆ‘j=1BiÎ·ij}}â‰¥T1absentsubscriptâ„¬subscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğµğ‘–subscriptğœğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğµğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‡1\displaystyle=\min_{\mathcal{B}}\left\{\max_{i\in[1,n]}\left\{B_{i}\tau_{i}+% \sum_{j=1}^{B_{i}}\eta_{i}^{j}\right\}\right\}\geq T_{1}= roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 , italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } } â‰¥ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
=miniâˆˆ[n]â¡{Ï„i+Î·i1}â‰¥miniâˆˆ[n]â¡{Ï„i}+miniâˆˆ[n]â¡{Î·i1}.absentsubscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğœğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–1\displaystyle=\min_{i\in[n]}\left\{\tau_{i}+\eta_{i}^{1}\right\}\geq\min_{i\in% [n]}\left\{\tau_{i}\right\}+\min_{i\in[n]}\left\{\eta_{i}^{1}\right\}.= roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } â‰¥ roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } + roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } .

Thus, the expected time to collect a batch BğµBitalic_B is

ğ”¼â¢[TB]â‰¥Ï„min+ğ”¼â¢[miniâˆˆ[n]â¡Î·i],ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‡ğµsubscriptğœğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\mathbb{E}\left[T_{B}\right]\geq\tau_{\min}+\mathbb{E}\left[\min_{i\in[n]}\eta% _{i}\right],blackboard_E [ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] â‰¥ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + blackboard_E [ roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ,

Note that if the distribution of miniâˆˆ[n]â¡Î·isubscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\min_{i\in[n]}\eta_{i}roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is heavy-tailed, then the expected time complexity becomes infinite, thus favoring MindFlayer SGD over Rennala SGD. A simple illustration of this occurs when extending the EquationÂ 3 case, where Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· is either zero or infinite, to scenarios involving multiple devices. In such cases, the expectation of the minimum time across devices, miniâˆˆ[n]â¡Î·isubscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\min_{i\in[n]}\eta_{i}roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, also results in an infinite expected time complexity.

While a detailed theoretical comparison is intractable, we conduct an empirical comparison to highlight practical differences between the two algorithms. To capture the randomness of Rennala SGDâ€™s rate, we generate a histogram: we create a histogram for TBsubscriptğ‘‡ğµT_{B}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and then convolve it Kğ¾Kitalic_K times with itself. Where Kğ¾Kitalic_K is the number of iterations required for Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-convergence.

The time complexity of Rennala SGD is a random variable that is the sum of Kğ¾Kitalic_K copies of TBsubscriptğ‘‡ğµT_{B}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where is Kğ¾Kitalic_K is the number of iterations to get Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-convergence.

For MindFlayer SGD, we evaluate two strategies for selecting tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: (1) using the median of the distributions ğ’¥isubscriptğ’¥ğ‘–\mathcal{J}_{i}caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and (2) solving the following optimization problem:

Fix mâˆˆ[n]ğ‘šdelimited-[]ğ‘›m\in[n]italic_m âˆˆ [ italic_n ], minimize tâ¢(m)ğ‘¡ğ‘št(m)italic_t ( italic_m ) over t=(t1,â€¦,tn)ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›t=(t_{1},â€¦,t_{n})italic_t = ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), (remember pj=Fjâ¢(tj)subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ¹ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—p_{j}=F_{j}(t_{j})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )).

We optimize this using the L-BFGS-B algorithm, a well-suited method for solving smooth, convex, or mildly nonconvex problems due to its efficiency and robustness (Zhu etÂ al., , 1997). For each mğ‘šmitalic_m, we take the minimum over all possible configurations.

Our empirical results, illustrated in Figure 3, demonstrate that as the variance of the underlying distribution increases, MindFlayer SGD consistently outperforms Rennala SGD. The heavy-tailed nature of the distributions causes Rennala SGD to experience extreme slowdowns, while MindFlayer SGD maintains robust performance.

6 Experiments

In this section we explain the setup for comparing MindFlayer SGD, Rennala SGD, and ASGD, which we used throughout this paper. We compare the algorithmsâ€™ performance on a quadratic optimization (4) task with access to a stochastic gradient. The parallelism was simulated on a machine with 2 Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6226R CPUs @ 2.90GHz, with a total of 64 logical CPUs. For each setting of the algorithm, we run 10 different seeds for the random time and plot the average, minimum and maximum, see FootnoteÂ 3, FootnoteÂ 5, etc.

We use a similar setup to the one employed by Tyurin and RichtÃ¡rik, (2024), but modify it so that we have a known expected variance. We make this choice, so we can compare theoretical parameters, as we did in FootnoteÂ 5.

Furthermore, we consider the homogeneous optimization problem (1), with the convex quadratic function

fâ¢(x)=12â¢xâŠ¤â¢Aâ¢xâˆ’bâŠ¤â¢x,xâˆˆâ„d.formulae-sequenceğ‘“ğ‘¥12superscriptğ‘¥topğ´ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘topğ‘¥ğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘f(x)=\frac{1}{2}x^{\top}Ax-b^{\top}x,\qquad x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.italic_f ( italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A italic_x - italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x , italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

We take d=1000ğ‘‘1000d=1000italic_d = 1000,

A=14â¢[2âˆ’10âˆ’1â‹±â‹±â‹±â‹±âˆ’10âˆ’12]âˆˆâ„dÃ—dandb=14â¢[âˆ’10â‹®0]âˆˆâ„d.formulae-sequenceğ´14matrix21missing-subexpression01â‹±â‹±missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionâ‹±â‹±10missing-subexpression12superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘‘andğ‘14matrix10â‹®0superscriptâ„ğ‘‘A=\frac{1}{4}\begin{bmatrix}2&-1&&0\\ -1&\ddots&\ddots&\\ &\ddots&\ddots&-1\\ 0&&-1&2\\ \end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}\quad\text{and}\quad b=\frac{1}{4}\begin% {bmatrix}-1\\ 0\\ \vdots\\ 0\\ \end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.italic_A = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 2 end_CELL start_CELL - 1 end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - 1 end_CELL start_CELL â‹± end_CELL start_CELL â‹± end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL â‹± end_CELL start_CELL â‹± end_CELL start_CELL - 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL - 1 end_CELL start_CELL 2 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and italic_b = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL - 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL â‹® end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (4)

Assume that all nğ‘›nitalic_n workers has access to the following unbiased stochastic gradients:

[âˆ‡fâ¢(x,Î¾)]j:=âˆ‡jfâ¢(x)+Î¾,assignsubscriptdelimited-[]âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğœ‰ğ‘—subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘—ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğœ‰\left[\nabla f(x,\xi)\right]_{j}:=\nabla_{j}f(x)+\xi,[ âˆ‡ italic_f ( italic_x , italic_Î¾ ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ) + italic_Î¾ ,

where Î¾âˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,0.00032)similar-toğœ‰ğ’©0superscript0.00032\xi\sim\mathcal{N}(0,0.0003^{2})italic_Î¾ âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , 0.0003 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), thus, we get that in 4.3 we have,

Ïƒ2=0.00032â‹…d=0.00032â‹…1000.superscriptğœ2â‹…superscript0.00032ğ‘‘â‹…superscript0.000321000\sigma^{2}=0.0003^{2}\cdot d=0.0003^{2}\cdot 1000.italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.0003 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_d = 0.0003 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… 1000 .

Now setting the convergence threshold Ïµ=10âˆ’4italic-Ïµsuperscript104\epsilon=10^{-4}italic_Ïµ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we can infer all theoretical parameters. To find the optimal time corresponding to Rennala SGD we need to fix the times, we do that by either removing the randomness, or adding the expected randomness.

On the other hand, for MindFlayer SGD we use the results from TheoremÂ 4.5 to set the theoretical number of trials for each client. In addition to the experimental results shown throughout the paper, we ran two more experiments. One with the Infinite-Bernoulli distribution on the same quadratic problem, and a second with the Log-Cauchy distribution with a small two-layer neural network on the MNIST (LeCun etÂ al., , 1998) dataset, see Figures 4 and 5.

In Figures 4 and 5, we observe key insights regarding the performance of MindFlayer SGD, Rennala SGD, and ASGD under different stochastic gradient scenarios.

FigureÂ 4 illustrates the behavior of the algorithms as we vary the probability of failure qğ‘qitalic_q in the InfBernoulli distribution. Notably, as qğ‘qitalic_q increases, both Rennala SGD and ASGD tend to stagnate, indicating their sensitivity to higher failure rates. In contrast, MindFlayer SGD maintains its optimization trajectory, demonstrating robust performance even in the presence of increased failure probability. This suggests that MindFlayer SGD is more resilient to stochastic disruptions, effectively continuing the optimization process without getting stuck.

FigureÂ 5 presents the performance of the algorithms on a two-layer Neural Network trained on the MNIST dataset, varying the scale parameter sğ‘ sitalic_s of the Log-Cauchy distribution. Here, we observe that MindFlayer SGD is less affected by larger variance of compute times, achieving convergence without significant delays. In contrast, Rennala SGD and ASGD experience notable delays with increasing variance, indicating that their convergence rates are adversely affected in such scenarios. This highlights the efficiency of MindFlayer SGD in handling high-variance, positively skewed computation times, making it a more reliable choice.

7 Conclusion and Future Work

In this paper, we address the problem of minimizing the expectation of nonconvex functions with Lipschitz gradients, with the use of parallel workers computing stochastic gradients. Our focus lies on the challenging scenario where worker compute times are heterogeneous and random, expanding on recent developments in ASGD methods like Rennala SGD. We observe that while Rennala SGD performs optimally in environments with deterministic compute times, its effectiveness diminishes under random compute conditions.

To better understand and improve stochastic optimization in these conditions, we introduce a novel asynchronous SGD method named MindFlayer SGD. This method adjusts to the randomness in computation times by not adhering to a fixed batch size but rather setting specific times for computing single stochastic gradients. If a client fails to deliver within this time frame, the computation is discarded, and the process restarts. This flexibility allows MindFlayer SGD to perform robustly across various conditions, notably outperforming both Rennala SGD and standard Asynchronous SGD (ASGD) in our theoretical and empirical analysis.

Our results demonstrate that MindFlayer SGD significantly reduces time complexity, particularly in environments characterized by positively skewed distribution of computation times. We empirically validate this in simulations with several distributions conditions where MindFlayer SGD consistently outperforms the other methods, particularly in high-variance scenarios. This showcases its superiority in adapting to the unpredictable duration of gradient computations typical in real-world applications such as federated learning environments.

In this study, our analysis was confined to computation times, with no consideration given to communication times. Future research will extend our investigation to include communication times. Moreover, we plan to explore the application of gradient estimators with varying variance bounds across different clients. We hypothesize that controlling these variance bounds could yield further benefits in the optimization process.

Ackowledgements

The research reported in this publication was supported by funding from King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST): i) KAUST Baseline Research Scheme, ii) Center of Excellence for Generative AI, under award number 5940, iii) SDAIA-KAUST Center of Excellence in Artificial Intelligence and Data Science.
